captions.text: I was intrigued by Dispatch and then I
was outtrigued and then I was intrigued
again. At first sight I was like, &quot;Ooh,
a quirky job simulator set in a
superhero universe. I do love the
justosition of the mundane and the
fantastical. It&#39;s like salted caramel or
choking yourself while jerking off. Tell
me more game.&quot; Gladly yacht. We&#39;re a
story-based choices matter adventure in
the model of the Telltale games that
were being released episodically. And if
you&#39;re wondering why the pitch of their
voice started lowering there, that was
something called the Doppler effect. And
it happened because I was running away
very fast. I thought we were over that
stupid episodic games thing. It didn&#39;t
save money or time like it was supposed
to. And by the time the last episode
comes out, everyone stopped giving a
[ __ ] after months of blue balls. Not
even particularly interesting. Hey, why
are you still here, Dispatch? Oh, don&#39;t
mind me. Just releasing all the episodes
on a regular schedule over the course of
a few weeks. Huh. Well, since I seem to
have temporarily shifted into a sensible
dimension, I took the opportunity to
binge Dispatch over the course of two
afternoons. And you know what,
listeners, I didn&#39;t hate it. In fact, I
sorry, I&#39;ve forgotten the word liked.
Liked. I liked it. Dispatch is set in an
alternative Los Angeles where
superheroes and super villains exist and
centers on Robert, a sarcastic dude with
no powers who fights crime in a robot
suit and who sounds like Jesse from
Breaking Bad if he switched to Downers.
His robot suit gets smashed up in a
super villain fight and he can&#39;t afford
to fix it. So, he&#39;s forced to accept the
reality of downgrading from robot man to
just plain Robert man. But when a hot
superhero lady representing a corporate
superhero agency, offers to repair his
robot suit and all he has to do in
return is act as dispatcher and mentor
for a ragtag group of squabbbling former
villains turned bottom heroes. Is the
offer too good to be true? No. No. It&#39;s
completely on the level and Robert gets
a fulfilling and interesting job and
works hard to impress his superiors,
including hot superhero lady who very
overtly wants to [ __ ] him. I thought
he&#39;d have some ethical issues switching
from independent to corporate
superheroics, but apparently that&#39;s not
something the story felt like
interrogating. I mean, they keep talking
about the people we&#39;re rescuing being
quote subscribers, which smacks of
protection racket to me. What do you do
if someone needs help but doesn&#39;t pay a
subscription? Do you just cordially
invite them to eat [ __ ] No, the premise
and setting don&#39;t really hold up to
scrutiny. I mean, this is a world where
superheroes and super villains are
treated like distinct communities and
even have their own pubs, but no larger
effort is being made to, you know,
arrest the super villains and stop them
committing crimes. It&#39;s framed more as a
lifestyle choice. Like one of the former
villains in our team tells us the story
of how she volunteered for the hero
program. And I was like, &quot;Bitch, this
was a voluntary thing. I assumed you
were arrested and this was the only
alternative to eating out sweaty Betty
in the prison showers.&quot; So, I&#39;d advise
trying not to overanalyze the broad
strokes of the story because the real
strength lies with the characters in the
dialogue. Robert could very easily have
been some gormless, naive everyman
reacting to all the capes and boob
windows with bewilderments and awkward
mouth noises. But no, he&#39;s a strong
character who fits into the world. He&#39;s
cynical. He&#39;s smart. He&#39;s capable. It&#39;s
believable when he earns the respect of
his charges. And I&#39;m very glad I only
found out in the end credits that he was
voiced by Aaron Paul because I know I
would have found that very mentally
distracting as he talks and I imagined
him jumping up and down yelling [ __ ] at
everyone. So I enjoyed the story quite a
lot on the character level.
Unfortunately, it&#39;s also superhero [ __ ]
So there&#39;s also a lot of action and
fight scenes. Very well animated action,
yes, but it does the Transformers
Saturday Morning cartoon, bollocks,
where 90% of the fighting is people
being thrown against [ __ ] and
immediately getting up with no apparent
injury because this is the universe
where everyone takes the extra spine
warranty and so nothing of actual impact
has happened. And unfortunately, it&#39;s
also post 2000 superhero [ __ ] and when
things with actual impact happen, the
tension must always be broken with a
quip because you can&#39;t spell nice long
bath in warm ostrich feces without baos.
Although I&#39;d say the writing and strong
characters keep things on the tolerable
side of Smammy, never quite crossing the
line into that dark foresaken land where
King Joss holds sway. And one area
wherein Dispatch breaks from the
Telltale game formula to its absolute
credit is that it remembers to be an
actual game. Who bloody ray only took 13
bloody years after The Walking Dead. In
each episode, there&#39;s a segment where we
do the actual dispatching with a
strategic management game sort of affair
in which we&#39;re given missions with loose
explanations of what skills are called
for and pick one or more available
superheroes with appropriate stats. And
it&#39;s all nicely presented and challenges
our intuition, decision-making, cool
down management skills, and occasional
good old-fashioned dumb luck, which is
pretty on theme. Honestly, if the game
had unlocked an infinite gameplay mode
after all the story bollocks was over, I
wouldn&#39;t have said no. Although, I
suppose it did help to take a break from
the stress with some nice character
scenes, and occasional momentous
decision over whether to say something
earnest or facicious, to change the
other characters next line of dialogue,
and absolutely [ __ ] all else. On that
note, I liked how your superheroes level
up and acquire new skills and quirks,
but I wish that had affected the story
more. Like the one dude who was a big
old nibbon, continued to be a big old
nibb in even though I&#39;d pumped his
charisma stats so high. His very farts
had started taking the form of dialogue
from broadly marketable romcoms. Well,
I&#39;m glad you enjoyed the game. Thank
you, dispatch. Are you planning to do a
replay and see the other story paths?
Absolutely [ __ ] not, Dispatch. I
still roll my eyes every time I see that
little text. So and so will remember
that. Oh, will they? So and so has a
functioning brain and the concept of
causality exists. Thanks for reminding
me. For a second there, I was
dangerously immersed. Replaying choices
matter games is the fastest way to
disillusion yourself on how much your
choices actually matter. Like there&#39;s
two love interests in the game pushed on
you rather blatantly. I quickly chose to
pursue the one with the actually
interesting story arc and did everything
to dissuade the other candidate short of
pushing dog [ __ ] up her nose. But she
still spent the whole game fluttering
her eyes like broadly marketable romcom
dialogue was coming out of my ass.
Here&#39;s the thing, listeners. Dispatch is
a good game in spite of, not thanks to
the Telltale format. If it had just
picked its most compelling story path
and swatted my hand off the mouse at
every choice, I&#39;d have liked it equally
as much. I liked the story and the
gameplay and the characters, the
writing, and the way it wasn&#39;t shy about
exploring relationships and sex and
naked boobies. Like a lot of popular
media these days that&#39;s primarily aimed
at audiences that haven&#39;t yet mentally
outgrown the notion that snogging is
icky and naked boobies are oppressive
and naked and lovely and boobies and
sorry I lost my train of thought.
Heat. Heat.
Heat. Heat.
